Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Type 1: A New Reliability-Assuring Computational Framework for Grid Operations under High Renewable Penetration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
While renewable electricity generation is considered key to a sustainable future, the variability and uncertainty of wind/solar generation at high penetration levels pose unprecedented challenges to grid reliability. In today's power systems, reliability is assessed by analyzing a set of contingency events, such as the loss of generators or transmission lines. However, these contingency-based methods are insufficient under large wind/solar ramping events, which become increasingly frequent and significant at high renewable penetration. Specifically, a large wind/solar ramping event should not be treated as a single contingency event. Rather, it must be modeled as an uncertain event-sequence that is sequentially revealed in time; yet the system operator must take immediate actions in the midst of such an event-sequence despite significant future uncertainty. Due to this critical difference, traditional contingency-based methods can no longer accurately quantify the resource requirement for reliability at high wind/solar penetration, leading to more costly dispatch of resources to offset poorly-managed uncertainty.

To address this open challenge, this CyberSEES project develops a new and mathematically rigorous computational framework for procuring and dispatching constrained grid resources, which aims to provably ensure reliable and economic grid operations under high renewable penetration. The project integrates reliability analysis at both the min/hour time-scales (for balancing demand and supply) and the second/sub-second time-scales (for dynamic security assessment). Specifically, the project team develops reliability-assuring online algorithms for day-head unit commitment and real-time economic dispatch at the min/hour time-scales, which provably balance demand and supply under large and uncertain wind/solar ramping events. Further, the online algorithms are tightly integrated with computationally-efficient set-based reachability analysis for assessing dynamic system security at the second/sub-second time-scales, which provides guaranteed bounds for dynamic system states in the presence of wind/solar uncertainty.

The success of this project will lead to paradigm-shifting advances in our ability to ensure power system reliability under high renewable penetration. At a broader scale, the results will contribute to the increased adoption of renewable energy sources worldwide, and will enable a smooth transition path to a sustainable future grid. The developed computational framework will also be applicable to small-footprint power systems, such as remote microgrids. Further, the results are expected to contribute to computation by advancing online algorithm design and reachability analysis, which will also be useful to other disciplines. The results of this work will be widely disseminated through conference and journal publications and actively shared with industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While renewable electricity generation is considered key to our sustainable future, the variability and uncertainty of wind/solar generation at high penetration levels pose unprecedented challenges to grid reliability. Traditional contingency-based methods for reliability assessment in today’s power systems can no longer accurately quantify the resource requirement for reliability under high wind/solar penetration, resulting into more costly dispatch of resources to offset poorly-managed uncertainty. To address this open challenge, this CyberSEES project at Purdue develops a new and mathematically rigorous computational framework for procuring and dispatching constrained grid resources, which aims to provably ensure reliable and economic grid operations under high renewable penetration. The completion of the project has produced the following significant results:

- We developed new approaches to determine, under a given level of renewable uncertainty, whether a set of generation and energy storage resources can guarantee demand-supply balance across the power grid in the future, and how to dispatch them in real-time to achieve such demand-supply balance. Compared to prior approaches in the literature, our solutions intelligently utilize the complementary capabilities of resources with different flexibility levels to significantly increase the amount of renewable uncertainty that can be accommodated. Further, they minimize renewable curtailment and lead to more economic use of energy resources.

- We developed new methods to assess the transient stability of power systems under significant amount of renewable uncertainty. Our method can ensure that the system remains stable at the moment of fault, despite the significant uncertainty in the future operation states of the generators due to renewable uncertainty. Our computational framework uses Taylor polynomials to significantly improve the accuracy and computation speed of the reachability analysis.

- We integrated reliability analysis at both the min/hour time-scales (for balancing demand and supply) and the second/sub-second time-scales (for dynamic security assessment). While these two reliability problems are mostly tackled in isolation in the literature, we demonstrated via a case-study that an integrated approach is feasible and can find a decision schedule that is reliable for both stages.

- We design new pricing schemes that utilize the demand side flexibility of data centers to improve power grid reliability. Our approach leads to a win-win situation where both the data-center and the power grid benefit through their interactions.

- We developed new method for reachability analysis of linear dynamic systems in continuous time, which can be used to compute time-domain bounds of states and outputs with high precision.

- We design competitive online algorithms for EV (Electrical Vehicle) charging that can significantly reduce the peak consumption level by leveraging partial future information.

Broad impacts of the project are the following. (i) The results from this project enable grid operations that can ensure power system reliability under high renewable penetration. (ii)  The results contribute to the increased adoption of renewable energy sources worldwide, and enable a smooth transition path to a sustainable future grid. (iii) The developed computational framework is also applicable to small-footprint power systems, such as remote microgrids. (iv) Further, the results contribute to computation by advancing online algorithm design and reachability analysis, which will also be useful to other disciplines. (v) The Ph.D. students and undergraduate on the project have been trained on a wide range of the topics in computation, algorithm design, and power-system analysis. (vi) The results of this work have been widely disseminated through conference and journal publications and actively shared with our industrial partners.
